channel.title: Using Libraries
channel.description: Hello, I was wondering if it is possible to access libraries without having them be in a jar file. Say I have the source and binaries and I want to be able to edit that code continuously yet still be able to use the library. Is that possible?

item.title: Using Libraries
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:33, topic:544964”]It’s fine to not use an IDE. Just don’t come to us when your compiler gives you problems :P[/quote]They normally share a similar compiler… Printing out the same errors. Some are just able to detect quick syntactical errors before compile time. It doesn’t necessarily mean the IDE is going to do all of the work for you.

And as with all tools, you have to figure out how to use them and get comfortable with them before they actually start helping you out.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:23, topic:544964”]Reasons to use an IDE:
keep formatting consistent
point out compilation errors/warnings before you actually compile
easier package navigation
easier refactoring
too many more to count

I like men

Reasons to not use an ide:
RAM (only if you have a shit pc)
learning curve (not very long at all)
being stubborn (main reason)[/quote]
I’m not converting to your religion, sorry.

Read full topic

item.title: Using Libraries
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I understand why people would be so adamant about using an IDE, but it’s absolutely not necessary. Only if you’re incapable of remember shit should you really need one. Even then, there’s documentation you can follow.

Read full topic

item.title: Using Libraries
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:20, topic:544964”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=663843.msg4437288#msg4437288 date=1405525694]

I could’ve sworn I’ve explained this before but it’s because I feel that IDEs are too bulky and complicated.

oh my god and you’re planning on making your own game without an IDE…

You guys are acting like it’s impossible. I began working on it May 5th of this year and I’ve gotten to the point where the game is actually playable.
[/quote]Use an IDE. Please.

You can learn a lot more without an IDE, so it’s quite educational. Although, Limits might get to the point of wanting one.

It’s easier to import libraries using the developer’s environment; choosing not to just means you will have to add a command into your batch file called -classpath <library_path>. You said you wanted it NOT to be in a jar file, so I guess adding the source files to your source package would suffice. That’s just a whole bunch of clutter in my opinion though.

I could’ve sworn I’ve explained this before but it’s because I feel that IDEs are too bulky and complicated.

oh my god and you’re planning on making your own game without an IDE…

You have little faith. I’m pretty sure anyone with basic core and graphics knowledge can write a game without an IDE.[/quote]
Thanks man and also for me it is easier to import libraries in a shell file than it is to import them in Eclipse. I used what I was raised on, which was TextMate.

Read full topic

You can learn a lot more without an IDE, so it’s quite educational. Although, Limits might get to the point of wanting one.

It’s easier to import libraries using the developer’s environment; choosing not to just means you will have to add a command into your batch file called -classpath <library_path>. You said you wanted it NOT to be in a jar file, so I guess adding the source files to your source package would suffice. That’s just a whole bunch of clutter in my opinion though.

You have little faith. I’m pretty sure anyone with basic core and graphics knowledge can write a game without an IDE.
